projects.name: (NSF REU) SURE: Speedier Simulations at the Illinois Institute of Technology
projects.summary: Quasi-Monte Carlo (QMC) methods offer improved efficiency when doing simulations involving random variables. In this program, I explored the use of QMC methods in numerically calculating the density of a function of random variables. I tested these methods in Python, working in and on the QMCPy repository
highlights: Investigated low discrepancy sequences and their application to kernel density estimation
Researched and implemented quasi-Monte Carlo density estimation with conditioning into QMCPy
Presented research biweekly for other students and faculty utilizing LaTeX and Beamer

projects.name: Illinois Mathmeatics Lab: Linear Poisson Structures and their Cohomology at the University of Illinois
projects.summary: Poisson structures are special geometric objects, originally arising out of classical mechanics. One particular class of them arises out of any Lie algebra, called a linear Poisson structure. In this project, we calculated the Poisson cohomlogy of different Linear Poisson structures (with power series solutions), which gave insight to the geometry of these structures. I also created Python and Sage code to be able to automatically preform these calculations.
highlights: Calculated Cohomology groups for various linear Poisson structures via power series
Wrote Python code to automatically calculate Cohomology classes with finite degree power series
Exhibited findings at Undergraduate Research Symposium and IML Poster Session
